en.value: Select the sentence with the verb "to do".
To recap, here are the phrases and language words we have learned, plus some others which might be useful.
I speak English and Spanish. My friend speaks English, Russian and Portuguese
Select the language names in the sentences below.
Listen to the audio. Which languages does Elisa not speak?
This question uses the verb "to do".
I speak a bit of Chinese.
Select the words in the correct order.
You come from France. - Do you come from France?
Let's recap! To form negative sentences, we use "do / does" + "not" + verb. To form questions, we use "do / does" + person + verb.
Select the language name that you hear.
Select the two words that make this sentence negative.
Make the following sentence into a question.
Did you notice? The verb "to do" changes depending on the person doing the action. Look at the forms of the verb "to do" below.
Match the question to the answer.
Match the pairs of words / phrases.
Listen and select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
Fill in the gap using the audio.
"To do" is a very useful verb in English. First, we're going to use it to form negative sentences and questions. Look at the examples below and on the following screens.
Fill in the gaps with the correct letters.
Write or talk about the different languages that you and your friends speak.
Select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
David speaks [h]German[/h]. He is from Austria.
He likes ice-cream. - He does not like ice-cream.
[k]We don't speak German|We do not speak German[/k].
We come from London. - We do not come from London.
We use the verb "to do" to form negative sentences and questions.
Read and listen to the sentence.
Select the verb "to do" in each sentence.
Asking and talking about the languages we can speak - Verb "to do"
Select the language names that you hear.
To form a negative sentence, we use the structure "to do" + "not" + verb. Have a look at the examples below.
They like coffee. - Do they like coffee?
Make the following sentence negative: "He speaks German". Write or record your answer.
Lucia is from England. She speaks [h]English[/h].
She speaks German. - Does she speak German?
Select the verb "to do" in each question.
[k]We don't|We do not[/k] come from Russia.
I speak German. - I do not speak German.
To form questions with the verb "to do", we use the structure "do / does" + person + verb. Look at the examples below.
